author: By Brad Stone
title: The Jeff Bezos Paradox
description: As the fortunes of Amazon and its founder have increased, their public images have cratered.
content: The latest creation from the technology giant Amazon occupies two floors in a shopping district in central London: a hair studio. Inside the 1,500-square-foot Amazon Salon, customers can visualize potential new hairstyles on the company’s tablets, buy shampoos and conditioners not available in drugstores, and order up things like a children’s haircut ($20), a roots tint ($62) or a thermal cut with heated scissors ($166).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Six rescue workers test positive for coronavirus at the Florida condo collapse site.
description: Chief Alan Cominsky of Miami-Dade Fire Rescue said that contact tracing had been performed and that hundreds of other workers had since been tested.
content: Six emergency medical workers helping with rescue efforts at the site of a collapsed condo in Surfside, Fla., have tested positive for the coronavirus, Alan R. Cominsky, the chief of Miami-Dade Fire Rescue, said at a news conference on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Errol Morris
title: Donald Rumsfeld’s Fog of Memos
description: The former U.S. secretary of defense was a man adrift in a sea of his own verbiage.
content: Trying to understand another human being is often a dismal task. And if not dismal, thankless. What am I supposed to do? Disapprove of Donald Rumsfeld? That’s easy. Perhaps too easy. He was ambitious, driven — also lucky. And, as we all know, he was one of the chief architects of the disastrous war in Iraq.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: I’ve Got a Feeling …
description: Follow your hunches in Howard Barkin’s Sunday puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — It is really nice to see Howard Barkin back in the New York Times Crossword puzzle, and on a Sunday. He is a software quality-assurance specialist in Hillsborough, N.J., and a speed solver who won the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament in 2016, earning him some lasting solving cred. His latest is a quick-paced, boisterous solve, with plenty of crackle in the fill and theme alike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward and Zach Montague
title: A North Miami Beach condo tower was evacuated over safety concerns.
description: NORTH MIAMI BEACH, Fla. — A 10-story condominium complex in North Miami Beach was ordered to close and evacuate its residents on Friday after the building submitted a recertification report, based on a January inspection, that documented “unsafe structural and electrical conditions.”
content: NORTH MIAMI BEACH, Fla. — A 10-story condominium complex in North Miami Beach was ordered to close and evacuate its residents on Friday after the building submitted a recertification report, based on a January inspection, that documented “unsafe structural and electrical conditions.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: Search and rescue work is stopped temporarily as engineers prepare for demolition.
description: Once sections of the site are safe, search and rescue work will resume, the mayor of Miami-Dade County told reporters.
content: Search and rescue work has stopped temporarily at the partly collapsed Champlain Towers South condominium in Surfside, Fla., while workers prepare to demolish the part of the building that is still standing, Mayor Daniella Levine Cava of Miami-Dade County said Saturday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Excesses of Antiracist Education
description: Structural racism is a real problem. The new progressivism is not necessarily a solution.
content: In my last column I tried to describe part of the current controversy over race and K-12 education — the part that turns on whether it’s possible to tell a fuller historical story about slavery and segregation while also retaining a broadly patriotic understanding of America’s founding and development.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Sternbergh
title: A Brawling, Go-for-Baroque Pulpfest
description: In S.A. Cosby’s new novel, “Razorblade Tears,” two fathers avenge their sons’ murders in great gothic geysers of blood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Travel and White House gatherings are back for the July 4 holiday.
description: About 48 million Americans are expected to travel over the holiday weekend, a 40 percent jump over last year.
content: A year ago, the United States celebrated Independence Day largely by staying home. The country staggered into that Fourth of July holiday weekend, having set records for new coronavirus cases in six out of the nine previous days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Steps to a Successful Garage Sale
description: Bargain hunters are back on the prowl after a year stuck inside. If you peddle it (neatly and at fair prices), they will come.
content: Q: We’re moving and have so much stuff to get rid of. Is it worth the effort to hold a yard sale? And how do we make sure it’s not a dud?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: Outdoor Art, Summer 2021
description: All in very different but concrete ways, these artists’ “live” public works speak of healing, history, and a fragile material world.
content: In post-lockdown New York, art has busted free from months of digital quarantine. Museums are open; objects are present, and people are pouring in — or at least queuing up for admission. The entrance line at the Met last weekend stretched across the plaza, and forward motion was slow. So, if you’re in need of a “live” art-fix fast — like, right now — you might consider another option: a self-guided tour of new outdoor art across town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Having an Outdoor Wedding? Here’s How to Prepare Your Skin.
description: From foundations and pressed powders to eye serums and lipsticks, these beauty products can help you withstand heat and other environmental elements.
content: As more weddings continue to be held outdoors, even as pandemic restrictions are lifted, beauty products will have to work overtime to fight prolonged exposure to heat and other environmental elements. But don’t sweat it — we’ve got you (and your face) covered with several products designed to provide long-lasting wear. Many are sweat, transfer and fade resistant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang W. Lee and Juliet Macur
title: Suspending Disbelief: The U.S. Gymnastics Team Takes Flight
description: At the U.S. Olympic gymnastics trials in St. Louis, the athletes vying for places on the team tested the limits of their ability, and of gravity.
content: If the United States Olympic gymnastics trials proved anything, it was that the arena ceiling at the Tokyo Games had better be high. There will be fast-flying flips and tornado-like twists that will need as much air as they can get.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: ‘I Didn’t Expect to Make It Back Alive’: An Interview With Tigray’s Leader
description: The leader of the restive Ethiopian region presented the rebels’ side of a conflict that plunged the country into chaos after Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed began a military operation there in November.
content: GIJET, Ethiopia — The convoy sped down from the mountain, slipping and sliding on roads greasy from a recent shower of hailstones. As it descended toward the regional capital of Tigray, curling through rocky hills and remote hamlets, people clustered along the route in celebration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman and Adam Rasgon
title: Cargo Ship, Recently Israeli-Led, Is Struck in High Seas Encounter
description: The attack, which did little if any damage, appeared to be the latest act in the shadow war between Iran and Israel.
content: A commercial ship that was previously owned by an Israeli-led company was attacked in the Indian Ocean on Saturday in what appeared to be the latest tit-for-tat in a shadowy regional conflict between Israel and Iran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Maria Varenikova
title: ‘Why?’ Ukrainian Army Faces Criticism for Making Women March in Heels
description: “Women, like men, fight in combat boots.” Recently released photos promoting an upcoming military parade received widespread criticism over the decision to make female cadets rehearse in heels.
content: The official pictures aimed to display the next generation of the Ukrainian Army: Dozens of female cadets marching in their fatigues and high heels, ahead of a parade next month for the country’s 30th year independence anniversary.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Salad, Any Way You Like It
description: We’ve got something for you, whether it’s corn, beans or noodles you fancy.
content: As summer trudges on, cooling salads offer a reprieve. It may come as little surprise, then, that Hetty McKinnon’s cold noodle salad with spicy peanut sauce (above) was the most popular recipe on New York Times Cooking this week, followed by Melissa Clark’s herby three-bean salad and Sue Li’s grilled corn and avocado salad with feta dressing. And for purists, there’s David Tanis’s Little Gem salad with garlicky almond dressing, requiring no more than five ingredients, refreshing in its simplicity.
source.name: The New York Times

title: N.Y.C. was ‘glorious’ without tourists. That time is coming to an end.
description: Last week, New York City tourism officials announced a $30 million ad campaign to lure tourists back. After a record of over 66 million visitors in 2019, the city envisions 36 million visitors this year and a return to prepandemic numbers by 2024, if not sooner.
content: Last week, New York City tourism officials announced a $30 million ad campaign to lure tourists back. After a record of over 66 million visitors in 2019, the city envisions 36 million visitors this year and a return to prepandemic numbers by 2024, if not sooner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Lauren Berlant, Critic of the American Dream, Is Dead at 63
description: Professor Berlant’s book “Cruel Optimism” provided a popular term to describe false hopes in an increasingly unequal nation.
content: Lauren Berlant, an influential scholar best known for exploring the effects on people of declining economic prospects and fraying social bonds in the 2011 book “Cruel Optimism,” which spoke to the frustrations of Americans reeling from the financial crisis of the late 2000s, died on Monday at 63 in a hospice facility in Chicago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt McCann
title: Hot Dinosaur Summer
description: Plus: Antarctica as a person, recycling bowling balls and "Jeff Who?"
content: Dinosaurs, which ruled the planet for roughly 170 million years and were one of the most successful animals ever, may have been in a 10-million-year decline at the time of their apocalypse, according to research published this week.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In Kabul, High Tension and an Air of Unreality
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 3, 2021.
content: “Afghans are leaving the country. I don’t know whether I am going to be safe 10 minutes from now.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Leaky Gas Pipeline Sparks an Inferno in the Gulf of Mexico
description: The fire burned for more than five hours before it was extinguished, according to Pemex, the Mexican oil company that controls the pipeline.
content: A leak in an underwater gas pipe sparked a swirling fire that raged for hours in the Gulf of Mexico on Friday, creating a biblical scene that drew comparisons to Mordor, the volcanic hellscape from “The Lord of the Rings.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Friends in High Places
description: Hanging with presidents: Sometimes First Friends are helping found a country; other times, they're mixing martinis.
content: WASHINGTON — When you are the president’s best friend, you may be called on for many services — some dicey, some soothing, some world-shaking, and some profoundly personal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hikari Hida and Shashank Bengali
title: Landslide in Japanese Resort Town Leaves at Least 19 Missing
description: A torrent of mud and debris washed away homes in Atami, about 60 miles southwest of Tokyo, after more than a foot of rain fell in 48 hours.
content: TOKYO — At least 19 people were missing on Saturday after heavy rainfall caused a mudslide that washed away homes and covered roads in debris in a resort town about 60 miles southwest of Tokyo, Japanese officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei, Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Alexandra E. Petri and Stephanie Saul
title: Inside the Tumultuous Years Before the Florida Condo Collapse
description: The condo board knew that Champlain Towers South in Surfside, Fla., needed major repairs. It did not know the complex was in a race against time.
content: SURFSIDE, Fla. — Elena Blasser kept her two-bedroom, two-bath condo in the Champlain Towers South as a beachside gathering place for family reunions. She adored the ocean and the small town of Surfside, Fla., because they reminded her of homes in Cuba and Puerto Rico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike McIntire and Russ Buettner
title: In Case Against Trump’s Company, Echoes of His Father’s Tactics on Taxes
description: The first criminal prosecution involving the former president’s business hearkens back to Fred Trump’s $16,135 purchase of boilers in the 1990s.
content: Long before Donald J. Trump’s company was accused of plotting detours around the tax code to compensate its chief financial officer with carpeting, televisions and car leases, there were the $16,135 boilers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
title: Danger Awaited in Myanmar. So He Made a Daring Bid to Stay in Japan.
description: After defying Myanmar’s military rulers at a soccer match, Ko Pyae Lyan Aung decided to seek asylum. But he was being watched.
content: OSAKA, Japan — The soccer player’s plane was at the gate. Ahead of him stood his last chance at safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Dr. Barbara Murphy, Kidney Transplant Expert, Dies at 56
description: Her focus was on immunology and how to predict and diagnose the outcomes of transplants. She was, a colleague said, “a great researcher and a great mentor to many people.”
content: Dr. Barbara Murphy, a leading nephrologist who specialized in advanced research that focused on predicting and diagnosing the outcomes of kidney transplants, died on Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan, where she had worked since 1997. She was 56.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Glanz, Mike Baker and Anjali Singhvi
title: Condo Wreckage Hints at First Signs of Possible Construction Flaw
description: Engineers studying the collapsed Florida tower said there seemed to be less steel reinforcement in certain areas than would have been expected from the 1979 design drawings.
content: Engineers who have visited or examined photos of the wreckage of the Champlain Towers South condominium complex have been struck by a possible flaw in its construction: Critical places near the base of the building appeared to use less steel reinforcement than called for in the project’s original design drawings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Hundreds of Businesses, From Sweden to U.S., Affected by Cyberattack
description: In Sweden, a grocery chain temporarily closed its doors after the attack. Some companies have been asked for $5 million in ransom.
content: Hundreds of businesses around the world, including one of Sweden’s largest grocery chains, grappled on Saturday with potential cybersecurity vulnerabilities after a software provider that provides services to more than 40,000 organizations, Kaseya, said it had been the victim of a “sophisticated cyberattack.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Liebelson
title: How Do You Convince Tough-Minded People to Protect One Another?
description: Combating vaccine resistance in Wyoming means first confronting the spirit of independence that runs across the West.
content: Living on his 25,000-acre ranch about an hour outside Laramie, Wyoming, 67-year-old Scott Sims figures he’s at lower risk of catching the coronavirus: He resides in relative isolation. A fourth-generation cattle rancher, he takes his vitamins, has never gotten a flu shot and regards himself as healthy. He wears a mask when required and washes his hands. But he hasn’t gotten vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: The Relics of America’s War in Afghanistan
description: Just a mile from Bagram Air Base, where U.S. forces departed on Thursday, shops sell items left over from two decades of fighting. Each one tells a story.
content: BAGRAM, Afghanistan — For almost 20 years, Bagram Air Base in Afghanistan was the anchor for America’s war, its sprawling twin runways serving to launch bombing raids, journeys home, medical evacuations, mail runs and U.S.O. shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Berlinger
title: Whitney Peak Has Fun on the ‘Gossip Girl’ Reboot
description: The teenage actress is also a brand ambassador for Chanel.
content: Name: Whitney Peak
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: How Indian Americans Came to Love the Spelling Bee
description: Since 2008, a South Asian American child has been named a champion at every Scripps National Spelling Bee.
content: Eighth graders aren’t generally known as dictionary aficionados. But Dhroov Bharatia, 12, has a passion for language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elsie Chen
title: These Chinese Millennials Are ‘Chilling,’ and Beijing Isn’t Happy
description: Young people in China have set off a nascent counterculture movement that involves lying down and doing as little as possible.
content: Five years ago, Luo Huazhong discovered that he enjoyed doing nothing. He quit his job as a factory worker in China, biked 1,300 miles from Sichuan Province to Tibet and decided he could get by on odd jobs and $60 a month from his savings. He called his new lifestyle “lying flat.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan and Andrea Kannapell
title: These are the U.S. states trying lotteries to increase Covid vaccinations.
description: Massachusetts and Michigan this week joined the parade of U.S. states that have introduced lotteries for residents who get Covid-19 shots, seeking to bolster vaccinations with titles like “Shot of a Lifetime,” “Vax for the Win,” “Comeback Cash” and even “Do It for Babydog” (thanks, West Virginia).
content: Massachusetts and Michigan this week joined the parade of U.S. states that have introduced lotteries for residents who get Covid-19 shots, seeking to bolster vaccinations with titles like “Shot of a Lifetime,” “Vax for the Win,” “Comeback Cash” and even “Do It for Babydog” (thanks, West Virginia).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: William Fagaly, Curator Who Focused on African Art, Dies at 83
description: In his 50 years at the New Orleans Museum of Art, he also made substantial contributions in the areas of Southern outsider art and contemporary art.
content: When William A. Fagaly was a graduate student in art history at Indiana University in the early 1960s, the professor in his area of concentration nicknamed him Intrepid. That pleased Mr. Fagaly, although he never understood how the word applied to him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brishette Mendoza
title: How a Slave Market Became a National Park Service Site
description: When driving through Natchez, Miss., it is easy to overlook Forks of the Road. But from 1833 to 1863, it was among the largest slave markets in America.
content: NATCHEZ, Miss. — When driving through Natchez, Miss., a town popular with tourists, it is easy to overlook an awkwardly shaped patch of land, only modestly marked by a few signs, free-standing exhibits and shackles cemented in the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Zetter
title: Hacking Wall Street
description: Could a cyberattack disrupt the financial system?
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz and Michael Levenson
title: 11 Arrested in Armed Roadside Standoff in Massachusetts
description: The men, who wore military-style gear and claimed to be “foreign nationals,” were part of an hourslong standoff with police officers.
content: Eleven men were taken into custody on Saturday after a lengthy roadside standoff between police officers in Massachusetts and a group of heavily armed men in tactical gear who claimed to be part of a group called Rise of the Moors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: We’ve Come So Far With Vaccines, America. Now Keep Going.
description: Many more people in the U.S. and abroad still desperately need the shots.
content: For all the missteps during its early days, the American coronavirus vaccination campaign is poised to go down as a triumph of science and public health. Seven months after the first shots were authorized for emergency use, 66 percent of adults — more than 100 million people — have received at least one dose. That’s not the 70 percent President Biden was aiming to reach by July 4, but it’s close, and it’s an impressive figure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Shashank Bengali
title: After another day without finding survivors, the rescue work enters a delicate phase.
description: Following another painstaking, dangerous and ultimately fruitless day in the search for survivors, the rescue effort at the site of the Champlain Towers South collapse appeared to be entering a delicate new phase, as officials and rescuers continued to quietly acknowledge the possibility that no more victims would be found alive, though they refused to abandon all hope.
content: Following another painstaking, dangerous and ultimately fruitless day in the search for survivors, the rescue effort at the site of the Champlain Towers South collapse appeared to be entering a delicate new phase, as officials and rescuers continued to quietly acknowledge the possibility that no more victims would be found alive, though they refused to abandon all hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Suicide Explosion Kills 10, Injures Dozens in Somalia
description: The attack in the capital, for which the terrorist group Al Shabab claimed responsibility, comes as the Horn of Africa nation begins a crucial election season.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — At least 10 people were killed and dozens injured in a suicide explosion in the Somali capital, Mogadishu, on Friday evening, the authorities said, the second such attack to rock the city in weeks as the country enters a crucial election season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: At an evacuated condo building, structural problems are disputed and residents’ lives upended.
description: When the city of North Miami Beach declared Crestview Towers unsafe, tenants had to clear out in a hurry. A lawyer for the condo board said the evacuation was unnecessary.
content: NORTH MIAMI BEACH, Fla. — Miguel Jiménez was busy at work Friday, detailing a car, when a neighbor called in hysterics. They had an hour to evacuate their apartments at Crestview Towers in North Miami Beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Iran’s president warns of a potential fifth wave as the Delta variant spreads.
description: President Hassan Rouhani urged Iranians to follow safety protocols to avoid more severe restrictions.
content: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran on Saturday warned that the country could see a fifth wave of coronavirus infections as the highly contagious Delta variant spreads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño and Flávia Milhorance
title: Brazil Vaccine Scandal Imperils Bolsonaro as Protests Spread
description: Brazilians were angry over how slowly their government moved to acquire coronavirus vaccines. Now they’re incensed over a corruption scandal involving vaccine deals.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — The plot twists of a coronavirus vaccine kickback scandal that has rattled Brazil’s capital have been worthy of a reality TV show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Crouse
title: Why We Hold Olympic Athletes to Such Ridiculous and Cruel Standards
description: A system that punishes athletes for being human is not a just system.
content: Sha’Carri Richardson, the 21-year-old American sprinter whose breakout victory in the 100-meter dash at the U.S. track and field Olympic trials in Oregon last month transformed her into an overnight star, posted a plaintive message on Twitter on Thursday afternoon: “I am human.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Took Shots With?
description: Come party on a Saturday with Kameron Austin Collins.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is quite a sophisticated venture, this latest offering from Kameron Austin Collins, who is blossoming as a regular themeless contributor. Regular solvers know to expect film references and linguistically fun debuts. (We have one in this puzzle that fits both bills.) I found the toughest challenge in the varied trivia topics today, but the only entry that completely stumped me was a weird little term with a long crossword pedigree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Mets Open Subway Series With Easy Win as Yankees Struggle for Answers
description: Yankees fans didn’t have much of a counterargument for the “Let’s go Mets” chants echoing in the Bronx.
content: Taijuan Walker took a no-hitter into the sixth inning, Brandon Nimmo provided a spark in his return from the injured list and the Mets beat the Yankees, 8-3, on Saturday to open a three-game set.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey and Aida Alami
title: Journalist’s Monthslong Hunger Strike Points to Perils of Reporting in Morocco
description: Soulaimane Raissouni, who has been held without trial for over a year, is more than 80 days into a hunger strike.
content: For years, Soulaimane Raissouni, a Moroccan newspaper editor, didn’t shy away from reporting on some of the most sensitive issues in the North African kingdom, including antigovernment protests that erupted in 2011 and 2016. But his criticism of how the authorities have handled the pandemic appeared to go too far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Pandemic Wave of Automation May Be Bad News for Workers
description: The need for social distancing led restaurants and grocery stores to seek technological help. That may improve productivity, but could also cost jobs.
content: When Kroger customers in Cincinnati shop online these days, their groceries may be picked out not by a worker in their local supermarket but by a robot in a nearby warehouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: June Finch, Virtuoso Dance Teacher With a Humane Touch, Dies at 81
description: A premier teacher of Merce Cunningham’s technique, she gave equal attention to everyone in her class, not just those destined for stardom with his company.
content: June Finch, a dancer, choreographer and teacher who specialized in the technique of the choreographer Merce Cunningham, imparting it to generations of students, died on June 18 in a hospital in Manhattan. She was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon revisit a chapter from U.S. history.
content: ACROSTIC — Today we have a somber reminder of the early days of the United States by a major museum luminary, Kinshasha Holman Conwill, who worked as the director of the Studio Museum in Harlem and is now the deputy director of the Smithsonian Institution’s National Museum of African American History and Culture. The excerpt is from “Dream a World Anew: The African American Experience and the Shaping of America,” an anthology book that commemorates the 2016 opening of this museum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Roger Federer’s Gift to Tennis: A Shot That Players Love to Hit
description: The squash shot may be a last-resort play, but it’s fun to unleash and spectacular to watch. Federer made it his own, but many other players, especially women, are adopting it.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — “Times have changed,” Roger Federer said this week as he looked back on his early days at Wimbledon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Trump Holds Rally in Florida, Across State From Building Disaster
description: Aides to Gov. Ron DeSantis questioned Trump associates about whether the event on Saturday night in Sarasota should proceed given the scope of the tragedy in Surfside.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump held a Fourth of July-themed rally on Saturday night in Sarasota, Fla., across the state from where a tragedy has been unfolding for more than a week as firefighters, search dogs and emergency crews search for survivors in the collapse of a residential building just north of Miami Beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Sophie Kasakove
title: The rest of the Surfside condo will be demolished within days, in a rush to beat a storm, officials say.
description: Gov. Ron DeSantis told reporters that the portion of the building that did not collapse is too dangerous to leave standing.
content: Florida officials said on Saturday that they were rushing to demolish the part of Champlain Towers South that is still standing because of worries that the partially collapsed structure would not withstand the powerful winds of an approaching tropical storm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: ‘Let the Birds Eat Them’: Crops Shrivel as Heat Wave Hits Washington
description: Farmers in eastern Washington, a leading agricultural region, face a blow to harvests. Amid the heat wave, others trying to cool down are diving into canals or just seeking refuge in the shade.
content: Stacey Sarty’s family has been farming in eastern Washington for generations. But it took the heat wave that scorched the Pacific Northwest this past week, in the middle of the cherry harvest, for the risks of growing food under such conditions to hit home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Lightning Close In on the Stanley Cup, and Carey Price Can’t Stop Them
description: Tampa Bay can win its second straight N.H.L. championship on Monday night with a four-game sweep of Montreal unless the Canadiens goalie can repeat his success from earlier in the playoffs.
content: Reasonable minds can disagree here, but: The most scrutinized position in sports just might be the starting goaltender in Montreal, where praise and criticism and comparisons to legends are doled out by the minute, in two languages, without so much as a break for lunch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Are Masks a New Signifier of Social Class?
description: Face coverings are coming off, though not for everyone.
content: On a recent Sunday night at Le Bilboquet, a see-and-be-seen restaurant in the Hamptons, well-heeled diners nibbled on $475 tins of Osetra caviar. A handsome man showed off his gold Audemars Piguet watch to his sparkly female companion. A party of 10 in polo shirts and striped rompers danced to a tropical house remix of Tina Turner’s “What’s Love Got to Do With It.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fleur Macdonald
title: As England’s Deer Population Explodes, Some Propose a Mass Cull
description: A pandemic-fueled expansion of the herds threatens the plant life that many species depend on for survival. But will the public accept killing many more deer?
content: CIRENCESTER, England — During a spring day of sun and showers in Gloucestershire in southwestern England, Mike Robinson, a restaurant owner and self-styled “hunter-gatherer,” was out counting the deer on his land. On any given morning he can see up to 40. He spotted a hind, a female deer, walking more cautiously than normal, a sign that she had company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Can the Senate Be Saved? Ben Nelson, the Manchin of Yesteryear, Has Doubts
description: A former Democratic centrist senator says too many lawmakers come to Washington to obstruct rather than be constructive.
content: WASHINGTON — The senator adamantly insisted on bipartisanship. As his fellow Democrats enthusiastically embraced major priorities of the new president, he threatened to withhold his crucial vote unless changes were made and Republicans brought on board. He was statistically the Democrat most likely to break with his party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Vatican Indicts Cardinal and 9 Others on Money Laundering and Fraud Charges
description: The charges stem from an investigation into a London real estate deal that lost millions.
content: ROME — A Vatican judge on Saturday indicted 10 people, including a once-powerful Italian cardinal, on charges including money laundering, fraud and abuse of office in relation to a London real estate deal and other investments in which it lost millions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: A Fourth of July Symbol of Unity That May No Longer Unite
description: In a Long Island town, neighbors now make assumptions, true and sometimes false, about people who conspicuously display American flags.
content: SOUTHOLD, N.Y. — The American flag flies in paint on the side of Peter Treiber Jr.’s potato truck, a local landmark parked permanently on County Route 48, doing little more, he thought, than drawing attention to his family’s farm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Congratulates New U.S. Citizens in White House Ceremony
description: President Biden hosted a naturalization ceremony at the White House on Friday for 21 new American citizens. The event was part of a federal effort to swear in almost 10,000 new citizens in celebration of Independence Day.
content: President Biden hosted a naturalization ceremony at the White House on Friday for 21 new American citizens. The event was part of a federal effort to swear in almost 10,000 new citizens in celebration of Independence Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Mudslide Washes Away Homes in Japanese Resort Town
description: Japanese officials said at least 19 people were missing after heavy rains caused a mudslide in the city of Atami on Saturday.
content: Japanese officials said at least 19 people were missing after heavy rains caused a mudslide in the city of Atami on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 3, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 3, 2021.
content: An article on Monday about a meeting between Israel’s foreign minister, Yair Lapid, and Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken incorrectly described management of the Temple Mount. The area is administered by an Islamic trust known as the Waqf, funded and controlled by Jordan. It is not managed by Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Debating the Morality and Value of Zoos
description: Some readers decry keeping animals in captivity while others tout the educational benefits.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
